text: (techno music)
- I am Taimur Rashid,

Head of Generative AI
Innovation and Delivery
at AWS.

Join me as I talk to
leaders and innovators

across Amazon who are
using AWS generative AI
to create hyper-personalized experiences
for customers, streamline operations,
improve productivity, and so much more.
Learn more inside gen AI at Amazon.
Today I'm joined by Asa.
And welcome to the show.
- Thanks for having me here.
- Yeah, absolutely.
So tell us a little bit about yourself
and what you do here at Amazon.
- Yeah, I lead the team that's responsible
for our tools and experiences
for our go-to market organization.
So if you think about solution architects,

account managers,
customer success managers,
they all need tools so we can engage
with our customers in the most proactive,
contextual way and we are really
building the tools and the experiences
for these teams.
- Okay, that's great.
And how are you using generative AI
to address some of these needs
of the sales teams?
- So I'll give you one example.
So at AWS, we always think customers first
and we work backwards from our customers.

And so one of the big
things that we wanna do
as we are getting our field teams ready
to engage with customers,
is to provide them the most relevant,
timely information about the customer

so they can engage them
based on their context,
their business needs, and so on.
So one of the first applications we built
with gen AI
was around Customer 360 data and research.

So we collect information
about the customer such
as their usage, their services,
their workloads from what we know,
but we also marry that

with publicly available
third party information.
So what industry is the customer in,
what is their priority,
you know, any key product launches,
any announcements,
how their exec teams are structured,
and so all of that information
can be put together in a very

easily consumable form
that our account managers
can access on demand
just when they're getting ready
for the meeting.
Or in other cases,
we can even push that to them,
when we know a meeting is coming up.
And so this really arms our field teams

to have the latest
information about the customer
so they can engage them in the right way
and give them access
to the right product, services, solutions
that they're looking for.
- No, that's great.
And in fact, it's great to see

that you're using the
working backwards process
and starting with the customer in mind

and then figuring out
what to build from there.
As you went through that process,
were there several sorts of use cases
or actual specific business problems
that you are looking to solve,
whether it was to drive more productivity

for the sales teams or
just reducing the time
that sales teams went through the process
of learning about an account?

- I like to think of
them as three main things

that we've been looking
at from a categories
of use cases perspective.

The first is customer
research intelligence,
and I'll go into all of these,
but so customer research intelligence,
being able to produce content
that is hyper-personalized,
and then information retrieval.

So those are sort of
the three broad cases.
So I'll give you a couple examples here.
So if you think about the customer
research and information pieces,
the Customer 360 is one example.

Another one is if you
think about our services,
if we can take information

about all the feature
requests from the customers
about our services, any support cases

that come along and find
are these friction areas
for the customers to use our services.
So we bring that together,

collate it again in a form
that's easy to consume

and we can feed that
back to our service team

so they can use it for
their roadmap management.

And you can think about
all kinds of scenarios

where you wanna make
information access easy.
The second scenario or the category
of use cases is around content generation.
So now think about you're writing an email
to a customer,
what if you got all of the context
for that customer put together
so you have a draft and then you can build

on that and send a really
personalized email.
All kinds of places
where we are creating documents
and creating content,
we can sort of get a jumpstart on that
by using the generative AI capabilities.
So that's the second category.
And then the third category
is around information access.
So, our teams need to act,

find out the most common
business processes,

how do I create a
private pricing agreement
or what are the common customer references

that I can use to share
back with my customer?

So, gone are the days
when you wanna go to wikis
and different documents
and try to search for info.
So we've brought all of that together
and using Amazon Q made it accessible
in a conversational way so our field teams

have the data at the
tip of their fingertips.

- Yeah, those are all
really exciting areas.
You know, 15 years ago I used
to be a sales rep myself
and I kind of wish I had some access
to these tools as a sales rep,
maybe I would've actually met my quota.
But that's great.
What are some of the benefits
you all are seeing so far?
I know it's still early days
with what you've implemented here,
but any early signals of benefits

that the teams are reaping
from this investment?
- Yeah, it's been, like you said,
it's early, but we are excited.
I think we look at the beginnings
of productivity improvements, right?
So the customer research that I mentioned
saves our teams anywhere
from 30 minutes to several hours
because that's the time they used
to spend collecting this data.
And now if you think about it,
we've generated over a hundred thousand
of those so far.

So you can think about
the tens of thousands
of hours saved
from doing relatively monotonous work
and they can now use that time
for more strategic thinking.
And that's kind of the beginning, right?
You can start helping with productivity.
But then what's exciting is one
of the favorite data points that I got
when we did some customer research on this
was at least a third of the people
that were using this capability

said they did not know
we had this information
about the customer

and they actually changed
the way they engaged
with the customer.
They were able to do more.
And so that's sort of the big benefit
is how do you access the nuggets
out of all of this information
so our teams can be more
effective with customers.
We are also seeing increase
in the size of opportunities,
the types of things we can do.
So there's the business outcome
that you can think about at the end of it.
And what's really worth's noting here is
that we can do this at scale, right.

When we are collecting
this detailed information

about a customer,
previously we could do this
for our larger accounts
or more strategic customers.
But now with this, you can do it at scale

for every customer, every
industry, every size.
And so you can really give
that hyper personalized attention
to every customer and really deliver
what they need in their context
because that context also changes, right,
who you're engaging with,
what business they're in.
And so that's really the benefit here,
which is we can do things

that are much more customer
focused and at scale.
- Yeah, no, that makes a lot of sense.
I wanted to shift gears just a little bit
and learn a little bit more
about the technology, right?

So all these great features
that you're bringing
to sales reps and field teams,
can you talk a little bit
about the underlying AWS technology,

more specifically the
generative AI services

that are being used to
power this experience?
- Yeah, we've been users of Bedrock and Q
from the very beginnings,
even before they went GA.
So we've been working closely
with the teams, getting access

to their latest features
and testing them out.

So a lot of the
fundamental work that we do
around summarization
and content generation uses Bedrock.

We use different models
based on anthropic,

but again, depending on
the type of function,
the type of use case,
we can use different models within that.

And then for our
conversational capability,
we are using Amazon Q for business
and that becomes a foundation
to create the knowledge bases
and start delivering the Q&A capability
based on that.
And then alongside that we use a lot

of the SageMaker
capabilities, the ML models
because you can then tie ML insights
with the generative capabilities to really
deliver a lot of what I was talking about.
- Yeah, it's great to see
all these building blocks coming together
to create a very tailored solution
for the sales teams.
Obviously you and many others here
at Amazon are trailblazing

with how to use generative
AI within their teams.
Can you tell a little bit

about a few lessons learned
that as others think
about doing something similar,

they can kind of learn
from those best practices?

- Yeah, well it's been
a fun journey, right?

It's like we are at the
forefront of things.
We are learning as we go.
But I think there's three key takeaways
if I look at our 12 to 18 months
of work in this area.

The first one is how data
and ML come together.
The second one is prioritizing based
on business outcomes.
And the third is how you need
to do more continuous testing.
And I'll elaborate on all of them.
So the data and insights piece.
Obviously a lot of this depends on data.
So having good,
clean foundational data is important.
As we brought this data together,
we realized sometimes there's duplicates,
sometimes there's missing data,
sometimes there is chain data
that's not being used as much.
So how can you be more prescriptive
about the data?
So we spend a lot of time on clean data.
The second lesson learned
was prioritization, right?
We are at the forefront

of so much excitement
that there's hundreds
of use cases that you can solve.

We literally have our
spreadsheets of a 100,
200, 300 use cases that keep adding up.
But it's really important
to be laser focused and prioritized.
It's easy to get distracted
and start doing a bunch of things,
but the areas that you focus on
should be both business impacting as well
as capable of being delivered
by the technology that we have today.
And lesson three is feedback, right?
So much of this technology is new
that earning trust with our teams,

making sure we are
building the right output,

that content is really
helpful is important.
So our teams spend a lot of time
with one-on-one conversations

with our early users,
get that feedback in.
We have at scale feedback.
So every single question and answer
or feedback you get the both up

and down versus the actual
qualitative feedback.
And then we kind of use our LLMs
to keep testing, right?
Is the content generated what's equivalent
to what the ground truth looks like?
So getting that continuous feedback
and training our teams to use it
because awareness change management
is equally important.
- Yeah, that's really exciting.
I really enjoyed this conversation
and thank you for sharing your experience
as you build this amazing technology
for the field teams.
- Thank you.
Thank you for having me here.
We are very excited and more than happy
to share our learnings and learned
from all other organizations
doing similar things.
(techno music)
